description:
Effective on March 18, 2020, all private and public schools and education facilities in Cameroon are to be closed. All public and private training establishments of the various levels of education, from nursery school to higher education, including vocational training centres and professional schools, will be closed; School and university competitions, like the FENASSCO and University games are postponed. 

Cameroon's Head of State announced on April 16, that schools will reopen on June 1, 2020. Exams for the 2019/2020 school year will take place in July and August. Cameroon will begin the 2020/21 school year on October 5th and October 15th (higher education). UPDATE: Schools in Cameroon, which were closed on March 18, will tentatively reopen on June 1, 2020. The 2020/21 school year is scheduled to begin on October 5th and October 15th (higher education).
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description:
UPDATE: Regarding the closure of schools in Cameroon, the Prime Minister and Head of Government, Chief Dr Joseph Dion Ngute announced on April 16, 2020 that all schools across the country will tentatively reopen on June 1, 2020. Schools have been closed since March 18.
This decision taken by the Head of State H.E Paul Biya is subject to change depending on the evolution of the pandemic in the country.

On March 18, 2020, the Government of Cameroon announced that all private and public schools, education and training facilities, at all levels of education, from nursery school to higher education, including vocational training centers and professional schools, would be closed until further notice; School and university competitions, like the FENASSCO and University games were postponed. UPDATE: Regarding the closure of schools in Cameroon, the Prime Minister and Head of Government, Chief Dr Joseph Dion Ngute announced on April 16, 2020 that all schools across the country will tentatively reopen on June 1, 2020. Schools have been closed since March 18.
This decision taken by the Head of State H.E Paul Biya is subject to change depending on the evolution of the pandemic in the country.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Preschool or childcare facilities (generally for children ages 5 and below)
institution_status: Preschool or childcare facilities closed/locked down

description:
The governor of the North-West region, Adolphe Lele Lafrique introduced a curfew in the North West region of Cameroon, prohibiting motorcycle use between 6PM and 5:30 AM. In a press release on March 16, 2020, the governor of the North-West announced that the circulation of motorcycles is prohibited between 6 pm and 5:30 am. Six of the seven municipalities which constitute the North-West region, are affected by the restriction. Only the Donga Mantung is not affected.

The curfew does not apply to vehicles of the defense and security forces, as well as ambulances.

The North West region includes the Anglophone region of Cameroon, where a deadly political and military conflict is ongoing.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: Cameroon's ministry of health released a press statement and preparedness plan for COVID-19 on March 7, 2020. The plan includes active monitoring for expected COVID-19 cases, active surveillance at points of entry, in-country diagnostic capacity at the national reference laboratory, and designated isolation and treatment centers. Temperature-taking devices have been installed at country entry points and are being used, alongside health declaration forms and information and sensitization materials.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Effective March 18, 2020, Cameroon’s land, air and sea borders will be closed. All international flights and all passenger flights from abroad will be suspended, with the exception of cargo flights and vessels transporting consumer products and essential goods and materials, whose stopover times will be limited and supervised: Cameroonians who wish to come back home should contact our diplomatic representations.
target_geog_level: All countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Effective March 18, 2020, Cameroon’s land, air and sea borders will be closed. All international flights and all passenger flights from abroad will be suspended, with the exception of cargo flights and vessels transporting consumer products and essential goods and materials, whose stopover times will be limited and supervised: Cameroonians who wish to come back home should contact our diplomatic representations. UPDATE: The original enforcer of the policy was the Cameroonian Federal government, but as of the related article on May 1st, the neighbouring countries surrounding Cameroon have also started to enforce prevention of outgoing travel from Cameroon especially over land borders.

All land, air, and sea borders remain closed and passenger flights from abroad are suspended. Only cargo ships and flights bringing food and essential items will be allowed to enter the country.

description: Effective March 18, 2020, Cameroon’s land, air and sea borders will be closed. All international flights and all passenger flights from abroad will be suspended, with the exception of cargo flights and vessels transporting consumer products and essential goods and materials, whose stopover times will be limited and supervised: Cameroonians who wish to come back home should contact our diplomatic representations. UPDATE: On March 31, President Biya of Cameroon extends coronavirus containment measures, implemented on March 18, for another 15 days. All land, air, and sea borders remain closed and passenger flights from abroad are suspended. Only cargo ships and flights bringing food and essential items will be allowed to enter the country. Authorities have also suspended issuing entry visas at airports. Government and public workers are also prohibited from traveling abroad.

description:
On April 23, 2020, the Head of State of Cameroon, Chief Dr Joseph Dion Ngute announced that despite the closing of Cameroon's external borders, six hundred and sixty-eight Cameroonians stranded abroad due to the Coronavirus pandemic will be repatriated, with expenses covered by the State. 

According to the Head of Government, negotiations are under way at the behest of the Minister of External Relations for the organization of special flights with the support of the countries and diplomatic representations of Cameroon concerned in view of the repatriation process.

In the same vein, Prime Minister Joseph Dion Ngute revealed the Government is facilitating the repatriation of foreigners wishing to return to their respective countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: All countries

description:
On April 10 Cameroon's Head of State Paul Biya approved the production of Hydroxychloroquine and Azithromycin for the purpose of combatting COVID-19.
On April 7, Cameroon's Minister of Public Health, Malachie Manaouda requested that the Minister of Scientific Research and Innovation, Madeleine Tchuenté, to start the production of Chloroquine.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The government of Cameroon has instructed regions to begin local production of medicines, protective masks and hand sanitizers by competent national institutions under the supervision of the Minister of Scientific Research, in collaboration with the Ministry of Public Health.

The Government of Cameroon has communicated seven new anti-COVID-19 measures, announced by the Prime Minister Head of Government Chief Dr Joseph Dion Ngute on Wednesday April 9, at the end of an inter-ministerial conference to evaluate strategies put in place to combat COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
The government of Cameroon has instructed the establishment of specialized treatment centers for COVID-19 patients in all regional capitals according to the field hospital model to receive patients in case of a peak of the pandemic and to allow other hospitals to operate normally. 

The Government of Cameroon has communicated seven new anti-COVID-19 measures, announced by the Prime Minister Head of Government Chief Dr Joseph Dion Ngute on Wednesday April 9, at the end of an inter-ministerial conference to evaluate strategies put in place to combat COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Announced on April 8, 2020, Cameroon’s ten regions will receive new anti-COVID-19 kits from the Ministry of Public Health to help local authorities in each region better fight the spread of the Coronavirus pandemic. At a press briefing on the situation of the Coronavirus in Cameroon, officials at the Ministry of Public health indicated that effective April 9, 2020 the process of detecting cases and their possible contacts will be handled in the new approach that equally involves local authorities. Regional governors are now responsible for coordinating COVID-19 responses within their regions. As such they announced that in the days ahead, all ten regions will be equipped with anti-COVID-19 kits given by the Ministry of Public Health to help them limit the transmission and spread of the killer virus at the local level.

This operation will be supervised by the regional governors and will enable the rapid detection of possible COVID-19 cases.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
On April 18, 2020, the Mayor of Batibo Council in the North West Region of Cameroon, Mr. Acha Kennedy, launched a public awareness and provision of health resources campaign within the municipality.

As part of the campaign, prevention information including posters , banners and flyers were distributed to the municipality, along with hand-washing basins, soap, sanitizers, and face masks.
date_end_spec: The policy has an imprecise natural end date (e.g. masks will be distributed until they run out)
target_geog_level: One or more cities within one or more countries

description: On April 24, 2020, a press release from Cameroon's Ministry of Public Health announced that health resources were acquired and redistributed to health personnel in charge of sampling, analysis and treatment, both at regional and municipal levels. These health resources provided by the state include more than twenty-five (25,000) coveralls, forty-five thousand (45,000) gowns, eighty-six thousand (86,000) protective masks (FFP2 or KN95), one hundred and fifty thousand (150,000) surgical masks, and three thousand two hundred (3,200 ) protective glasses.

description: On April 24, 2020, a press release from Cameroon's Ministry of Public Health announced that health resources were acquired and redistributed to health personnel in charge of sampling, analysis and treatment, both at regional and municipal levels. These health resources provided by the state include more than twenty-five (25,000) coveralls, forty-five thousand (45,000) gowns, eighty-six thousand (86,000) protective masks (FFP2 or KN95), one hundred and fifty thousand (150,000) surgical masks, and three thousand two hundred (3,200 ) protective glasses.

The health resources provided include hygienic products and medical kits, 50,000 cartons of laundry soap, 1.5 million face masks for the population, 50,000 surgical masks for health workers, 75 thousand buckets for household use, 40,000 hand washing cans, rapid screening test kits and respiratory devices for hospitals.

description:
On May 26, 2020 in Cameroon, the Vice President of Cameroon’s Senate donated health resources including hygiene and sanitation kits and food items to vulnerable persons in eleven subdivisions in the Littoral region to fight against the rapid spread of Coronavirus pandemic.

The gifts were handed over to the mayors of these Council areas Tuesday May 26.

description: The Minister of Public Health invites those who arrived in Cameroon by air (plane) since March 10, all flights combined, to urgently call in and be tested for COVID-19. Announced March 28, 2020, the Ministry of Health reserves the right to use the list of these passengers to ensure their identification and tracing by the teams of the Ministry of Public Health, with a view to test them in laboratories approved for this purpose.
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Announced March 30, 2020, Cameroon's Ministry of Public Health will begin a door-to-door testing campaign from April 4 to April 7 in the Littoral Region of Cameroon, which includes Cameroon's largest city Douala. Teams from the Ministry of Public Health will move from door-to-door to ensure the whole population of the Littoral region are aware of precautionary measures against the COVID-19 pandemic and if deemed necessary they will be screened. Nearly 1,500 community health workers are mobilized, and supported by the Urban Community of Douala and the city halls of the city districts. Laboratories have been equipped to henceforth test and analyze results of screened samples in the Littoral region.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description:
The government of Cameroon has instructed the intensification of the COVID-19 screening campaign, with the collaboration of Centre Patteur and its branches as well as other relevant health institutions. Emphases will be laid on already identified affected areas.

The Government of Cameroon has communicated seven new anti-COVID-19 measures, announced by the Prime Minister Head of Government Chief Dr Joseph Dion Ngute on Wednesday April 9, at the end of an inter-ministerial conference to evaluate strategies put in place to combat COVID-19.

description: Effective March 18, 2020 Cameroon is enforcing a strict reduction of public transport. Reduction of public transports to the 'strict minimum'. Drivers of buses, taxis and motorbikes are urged to avoid overloading: law enforcement officers will ensure they comply; Urban and inter-urban travel should only be undertaken in cases of extreme necessity. In addition to requiring the disinfection of public transport vehicles, the number of allowed passengers in city cabs/taxis has been reduced to 3, and the number of passengers in inter-city transport buses has been reduced to 50, threatening severe administrative and pecuniary penalties for any offenders.

description:
Effective March 18, 2020 Cameroon is enforcing a strict reduction of public transport. Reduction of public transports to the 'strict minimum'. Drivers of buses, taxis and motorbikes are urged to avoid overloading: law enforcement officers will ensure they comply; Urban and inter-urban travel should only be undertaken in cases of extreme necessity. In addition to requiring the disinfection of public transport vehicles, the number of allowed passengers in city cabs/taxis has been reduced to 3, and the number of passengers in inter-city transport buses has been reduced to 50, threatening severe administrative and pecuniary penalties for any offenders.
Restrictions reducing the mandatory number of passengers in all public transport by bus and taxi were lifted on April 30, 2020. The wearing of masks remains compulsory and overloading is prohibited. UPDATE: Restrictions reducing the mandatory number of passengers in all public transport by bus and taxi have been lifted on April 30, 2020. The wearing of masks remains compulsory and overloading is prohibited.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Legal Penalties (Jail Time),Mandatory with Fines

description:
On April 16, 2020 Cameroon's President ordered the commuting of prison sentences in Cameroon's 78 state prisons to reduce overcrowding and the risk of transmitting COVID-19. The policy excludes political opponents, separatists from Cameroon's Anglophone region in the North West and South West Regions, and journalists critical of the regime. 

Under the presidential decision, life sentences are reduced to 25 years, those for whom life sentences had already been reduced to 25 years will have five years taken off their sentences. Ten-year sentences will be cut by three years, five-year sentences will be cut by two years, and three-year sentences will be cut by one year.
type_text: This policy commutes the prison sentences of some prisoners in prisons across Cameroon to prevent overcrowding and virus transmission.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
On April 16, 2020, Cameroon's President ordered the commutation of prison sentences across the country in 78 state prisons in order to reduce overcrowding and the risk of spreading COVID-19. Political prisoners and separatists from Cameroon's Anglophone North-West and South-West Regions are excluded from the policy. 

Under the presidential decision, life sentences are reduced to 25 years, those for whom life sentences had already been reduced to 25 years will have five years taken off their sentences. Ten-year sentences will be cut by three years, five-year sentences will be cut by two years, and three-year sentences will be cut by one year.
type_text: This policy affects the sentences of prisoners in Cameroon's state prisons. The Government ordered the commutation of sentences to reduce overcrowding and risk of spreading COVID-19.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: La Banque Africane de Développement (BAD) approved a loan of approximately of 88 million Euros (57 billion CA Francs or 98 million USD) in order to help fund crisis management and CORONA response in Cameroon after the press conference on June 23rd, reported June 26th.
type_text: The policy is an outgoing loan from the BAD to the government of Cameroon after the request to receive aid to combat the Corona Virus

description: On April 1, Cameroon's Minister of Public Health announced over Twitter that individuals should wear face masks when going outside.

The mayor of the city of Douala in Cameroon announced April 6, 2020 that wearing a mask will be mandatory to slow the spread of the deadly coronavirus that has already infected 658 people across the country. Roger Mbassa Ndine, mayor of the coastal city of Douala, made the announcement Monday as crews began  fanning out across the city Monday to pass out washable masks, in a new awareness campaign that will take them to other boroughs in the coming days.

The mayor of the city of Douala in Cameroon announced April 6, 2020 that wearing a mask will be mandatory to slow the spread of the deadly coronavirus that has already infected 658 people across the country. Roger Mbassa Ndine, mayor of the coastal city of Douala, made the announcement Monday as crews began fanning out across the city Monday to pass out washable masks, in a new awareness campaign that will take them to other boroughs in the coming days. Local police and security forces are enforcing compliance in Douala. UPDATE: This policy is being enforced by security/police forces

The government of Cameroon has instructed the intensification of the awareness-raising campaign in urban and rural areas both in the two official languages (English and French) and in local languages through complementary channels of communication to be defined by the Minister of communication with the support of administrative, municipal, traditional and religious authorities.

The Government of Cameroon has communicated seven new anti-COVID-19 measures, announced by the Prime Minister Head of Government Chief Dr Joseph Dion Ngute on Wednesday April 9, at the end of an inter-ministerial conference to evaluate strategies put in place to combat COVID-19.
enforcer: National Government,Ministry/Department of Health,Provincial/State Government,Municipal Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On April 1, Cameroon's Minister of Public Health announced over Twitter that individuals should wear face masks when going outside. On April 10, the Prime Minister of Cameroon announced that the use of a face mask in Cameroon will be made compulsory effective April 13, 2020 in a bid to stem the rapid propagation of the virus.
This additional measure was announced by the Prime Minister Joseph Dion Ngute after holding an interministerial evaluation meeting of the COVID-19 situation in Cameroon.
 UPDATE: The Government of Cameroon has now made the wearing of face masks mandatory beginning April 13
On July 25th the Health Minister of Cameroon announced that the curve of the virus has begun to flatten but still urges everyone to respect the issuance in place.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 16th, the government of Cameroon has urged all travelers coming into Cameroon from countries affected by the COVID-19 to self quarantine for fourteen days. Any person who has travelled out of Cameroon or has been in contact with a traveller from countries affected by the COVID-19 and presenting symptoms such as runny nose, cough and/or fever, should immediately call 1510 to receive appropriate treatment. As for people from countries at risk and their respective families, the Health Minister asked them to be more responsible and facilitate the response mechanism and protect the community by observing a quarantine of 14 days before any activity or contact with anybody.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective March 31, 2020, drinking in off-licences, bars and other drinking spots and eating in restaurants has been prohibited in the South West region of Cameroon as a way to curb the rapid spread of the Coronavirus pandemic. The decision is contained in a release signed by the South West regional governor, Bernard Okalia Balia, dated Tuesday March 31, 2020. According to the release, all those who will buy food from restaurants and drinks from drinking spots will have to take them home for consumption.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: The Mayor of Douala 2, (the 2nd district of Douala) Denise Fampou announced March 31, 2020 in a press release that all markets in Douala 2 will be closed on April 2, 2020 for full disinfection and cleaning. Following the disinfection and the reopening of markets, each trader must now wear a mask and install a hand washing device or a hydro-alcoholic disinfection solution in front of their shop. Traders operating in the women's market and the goat market were also asked to each contribute up to 1,000 FCFA or have their businesses immediately shut down. Because, she justifies, "the fight concerns everyone".
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
institution_status: This type of business  ("Retail Businesses") is closed/locked down

description: Effective April 2, 2020, the Governor of the Littoral Region of Cameroon has further restricted non-essential businesses, limiting restaurants and bars by prohibiting the consumption of food or drinks in public spaces. In a release signed by the Littoral Governor, Samuel Dieudonne Ivaha Diboua dated April 2, the population of the region is invited to take home every eatable and drinkable stuff they buy from their selling points. This decision seeks to limit the unnecessary gathering of people in restaurants, commercial enterprises and drinking spots, a move that will ensure many stay home as much as possible to stop the spread of the Coronavirus pandemic. In the communique, Governor Samuel Dieudonne Ivaha Diboua notes that forces of law and order and Administrative officials will have to ensure that this decision is respected.
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)

description:
On March 17, 2020 the President of the Republic of Cameroon announced that from Wednesday 18 March 2020, till further notice: under the supervision of administrative authorities, bars, restaurants and entertainment spots will be systematically closed after 6 p.m.
On April 30, 2020, bars, restaurants and leisure facilities in Cameroon are now permitted to open even after 6 PM, although customers and users are still required to respect social distancing measures, in particular the wearing of protective masks. UPDATE: Announced April 30, 2020, Bars, restaurants and leisure facilities in Cameroon are now permitted to open after 6 PM, although customers and users are still required to respect social distancing measures, in particular the wearing of protective masks.

On March 17, 2020 the President of the Republic of Cameroon announced that from Wednesday 18 March 2020, till further notice: under the supervision of administrative authorities, bars, restaurants and entertainment spots will be systematically closed after 6 p.m. UPDATE: Prime Minister Ngute announced as of May 1st that Cameroon will allow bars, restaurants and nightclubs to reopen, but customers will be required to adhere to some guidelines including the wearing of face masks and maintaining social distancing.

On March 17, 2020, Cameroon announced that from the 17th of March, 2020, public administration shall give preference to electronic communication and digital tools for meetings likely to bring together more than ten people.

description: Effective March 18, 2020, the Government of Cameroon is restricting gatherings of people. Gatherings of more than 50 people are forbidden throughout the national territory. All places for public and private gathering are hereby ordered to close. Public administrations are required to give preference to electronic communications and digital tools for meetings likely to bring together more than ten (10) people. A system for regulating consumer flows will be set up in markets and shopping centers. Violations of the policy have been enforced by local authorities, including shutting places of worship, businesses, and markets that do not comply with regulations.
Announced April 4, 2020, in the 1st district of the city of Douala in Cameroon, marriage celebrations have been suspended until further notice.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description:
The government of Cameroon has implemented a restriction on mass gathering, cancelling this year’s National Unity Day celebrations on May 20th and Labour Day celebrations planned for May 1st, due to the coronavirus pandemic. 
The cancellations were announced on April 22, 2020, in a release signed by the Minister of State, Secretary-General of the Presidency of the Republic, Ferdinand Ngoh Ngoh.
type_sub_cat: Cancellation of an annually recurring event

description: On June 3, the Governor of the Central Region of Cameroon announced that funeral services and rites are banned to prevent the spread of COVID-19. There continues to be a ban on gatherings of more than 50 people. This ban was implemented in particular due to violations of the existing restrictions.
